title: Room to Read: Yearly Alumnae Survey
text:
Room to Read’s Girls’ Education Program equips girls with the skills and support they need to stay in school, make informed choices, and chart a path toward a more gender-equal future.
      This survey compares alumnae outcomes one year and five years after graduation, across eight countries, focusing on Agency, Education, Employment, and Marriage & Children.
    
    

    
      2+ years of data
      1,000+ stories
      8 countries

title: Room to Read: Yearly Alumnae Survey

title: Room to Read: Yearly Alumane Survey
text:
Focus on Agency
Agency is the ability to face a disagreement and resolve it successfully.
Agency is a core outcome of the Girls’ Education Program.
It reflects how alumnae work through family disagreements on education, marriage, finances, mobility, and body autonomy.
Explore Agency in depth

Agency Education Employment Marriage & Children

title: Room to Read: Yearly Alumnae Survey
section: Agency is the ability to face a disagreement and resolve it successfully.
text:
Agency is the ability to face a disagreement and resolve it successfully.
It’s a core outcome of the Girls’ Education Program—and it’s how alumnae work through family disagreements on the topics below.

       Education 
       Employment 
       Marriage 
       Children

title: Room to Read Alumnae Survey
text:
This page will have visualizations that cover the following questions:
In which countries do alumnae report the highest frequency of disagreements with family on key life decisions (education, marriage, work, mobility, finances, body autonomy)?
How often are these disagreements resolved favorably, and does resolution differ between 1-year and 5-year cohorts?
Are certain disagreement topics (like education or finances) more likely to be resolved favorably across different contexts?
How does Agency relate to subsequent choices in education, work, or marriage?
Example of what a viz could look like:

library(tidyverse)

# Brand palette
brand <- list(
  teal   = "#007AA4",
  green  = "#0C6F5A",
  yellow = "#FFC142",
  pink   = "#994263"
)

# Theme
theme_rtr <- function() {
  theme_minimal(base_family = "Georgia") +
    theme(
      plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 18, color = "#111"),
      plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12, color = "#333"),
      axis.title = element_text(size = 11, color = "#333"),
      axis.text  = element_text(size = 10, color = "#333"),
      panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
      panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
      plot.margin = margin(6, 6, 6, 6)
    )
}


# Data
